field_reports.summary: AUS: Flood - 05-2025 - Severe Weather New South Wales
field_reports.description:
On Monday 19 May the Hunter Vally, Central and Mid-North Coast regions of NSW were impacted with a significant weather event bringing ongoing heavy rain and storms. Multiple weather warnings were issued with several Minor to Major flood warnings for local rivers. The State Emergency Service (SES) issued five Emergency Warnings. A coastal trough brought heavy ongoing rain and storms.

Receiving 427 millimetres (16.8 in) of rain over two days, Taree had the wettest May on record and experienced one-third of its annual average rainfall from 19 to 21 May. Taree also experienced the highest floodwaters in more than 90 years.[1] 

Subsequent flooding has resulted in hundreds of people being rescued by the SES. Flooding at unprecedented levels has inundated towns and left residents stranded in the Mid North Coast and Hunter region of New South Wales, with parts of Taree, Wingham and Glenthorne of most concern.

Animal and stock losses are of great concern with many farmers having had their herds of cattle wiped out by the flooding and worries about how to feed their remaining livestock.

As of midday 23 May,  there are nearly 150 warnings in place and 50,000 people in areas where they should prepare to evacuate. 

More than 23,000 dwellings have been isolated by flood waters with SES having completed over 765 flood rescues. Early estimates suggest over 10,000 properties may be damaged after record flooding.

results.summary:

results.name: AUS: Flood - 05-2025 - Severe Weather New South Wales

field_reports.description: Ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred reached Queensland Moreton Bay islands in the early hours of Saturday 08 March. The cyclone impact is estimated to be a 300km (190-mile) stretch of coastline from Maroochydore on the Sunshine Coast to Byron Bay in New South Wales. Flood and severe weather warnings are in place with evacuation orders issued, stretching over dozens of communities in south-eastern Queensland and northern New South Wales. Storm surges have already caused significant damage to parts of the east coast, with the cyclone producing winds in excess of 100 kilometres an hour. Authorities remain concerned about the impact of flooding and thunderstorms, which could bring more damaging wind and heavy rain. At the time of reporting more than 42,000 homes and businesses in New South Wales are without power and 290,000 without power in Queensland. Schools are closed in both states, with road, public transport and airport closures also impacting affected communities and emergency services response. Nine evacuation centres are open across southeast Queensland and 19 across northern New South Wales.

results.summary: Ex-Tropical Cyclone Alfred reached Queensland Moreton Bay islands in the early hours of Saturday 08 March. The cyclone impact is estimated to be a 300km (190-mile) stretch of coastline from Maroochydore on the Sunshine Coast to Byron Bay in New South Wales. Storm surges have already caused significant damage to parts of the east coast, with the cyclone producing winds in excess of 100 kilometres an hour. Authorities remain concerned about the impact of flooding and thunderstorms, which could bring more damaging wind and heavy rain. At the time of reporting more than 42,000 homes and businesses in New South Wales are without power and 290,000 without power in Queensland. Schools are closed in both states, with road, public transport and airport closures also impacting affected communities and emergency services response. Nine evacuation centres are open across southeast Queensland and 19 across northern New South Wales.
results.name: AUS: Cyclone - 03-2025 - TC Alfred - NSW/QLD

field_reports.summary: AUS: Flood - 01-2025 - North Queensland Weather Event
field_reports.description:
On 29 January 2025 a severe weather event caused by two tropical lows resulted in record breaking flood conditions impacting much of North and Far North Queensland. Severe weather warnings stretched from the Gulf Country, across the tropical coast and into the Burdekin Region.

The flooding resulted in evacuations of people with impacts to homes, small business, and to communities at large. Some communities were isolated as a result of flood waters with some areas relying on supply drops from helicopters and planes. Power networks and the road transport system were heavily affected. 

All levels of government, including local, state and the Commonwealth are providing support to the response, early relief and recovery required for this event.

Australian Defence Force personnel deployed in addition to members of emergency services from other states and territories.

Key financial assistance measures announced by the government, include the Australian Government Disaster Relief Allowance and the Australian Government Disaster Relief Payment. There are also a range of other payments available through the state of Queensland.. 5,690 insurance claims have been lodged as at 16/02/2025.

results.name: AUS: Flood - 02-2025 - North Queensland Weather Event

field_reports.description:
On 22 February, a large fire started near the town of Beaufort, approximately 50kms from Ballarat in Western Victoria which threatened communities in the area. Several Emergency Leave Now Warnings were issued, although these have been downgraded to Not Safe to Return. Emergency Relief Centres (ERCs) were opened in Ballarat, Maryborough, and Ararat, with Ararat and Maryborough still operating. The fire is not yet under control.

Extreme fire weather is expected in the middle of the week, particularly Wednesday 28 with the Chief CFA Officer and the Premier warning Victorians to prepare for the possibilities of more bushfires.

results.summary:
On 22 February, a large fire started near the town of Beaufort, approximately 50kms from Ballarat in Western Victoria which threatened communities in the area. results.name: AUS: Fire - 02-2024 - AUS: Ballarat Bushfires - 02-2024

field_reports.summary: AUS: Flood - 01-2024 - QLD Severe Weather Jan-Feb 2024
field_reports.description:
Tropical Cyclone Kirrily formed on Thursday 25 January 2024 and made landfall as a category 3 cyclone overnight and quickly weakened to a tropical low.

The resulting Tropical Low has produced HEAVY to INTENSE RAINFALL and DAMAGING WINDS to parts of the northern interior and western Queensland. As at 0600 hours 28 January, Ex-Tropical Cyclone Kirrily will remain over inland Queensland in coming days, bringing the risk of significant and widespread rain and flooding to areas of the northern interior, central and western Queensland. 

The low is likely to remain slow moving during the week with potential to move north towards the Gulf of Carpentaria, northwest over the NT or even towards the east coast of north Queensland. At this stage the likelihood of it redeveloping into a tropical cyclone is very low.  

 

On 25 January a cyclone shelter and a place of refuge were opened in Townsville in preparation for TC Kirrily making landfall. In total, nineteen (19) people presented to the Heatley cyclone shelter and 9 people presented at the Townsville refuge in the shelter. 

Whilst Kirrily did not bring the anticipated destruction, the impacts are still being felt by thousands of homes. As at 0600 28 January 23,000 homes remain without power, with Townsville City Council encouraging residents to continue conserving water as the city’s water infrastructure is impacted due to power outage. Townsville City Council have noted health concerns among vulnerable residents due to loss of power and are prioritising access to generators. National Broadband Network and voice data services remain impacted with over 8800 services being affected. On ground rapid impact assessments continue.  

 

As at 27 January, 783 damage assessments have been completed with 35 properties identified as having sustained minor to moderate damage. A number of roads also continue to remain closed due to flash flooding, road damage and debris. Across the state, 16,000 tonnes of incoming freight (including 11,000 tonnes of mining materials) is being blocked. Many communities along the Gulf of Carpentaria remain isolated due to road closures, including Burketown, Doomadgee Normanton, and Gregory.

 

Joint Commonwealth-state Disaster Recovery Funding Arrangements (DRFA) have been activated to fund counter disaster operations for Burdekin and Hinchinbrook Shire Councils, Palm Island Aboriginal Shire Council and Townsville City Council. The Queensland Government has announced disaster support for communities affected by Tropical Cyclone Kirrily.

Personal hardship financial assistance is now available to residents in Burdekin Shire and Townsville City Local Government Areas. This includes Emergency Hardship, Essential Services Hardship Assistance, Essential Services Safety and Reconnection and Housing assistance is available for residents affected by this event.

As at 29 January six (6) Recovery Hubs will be operating across the Townsville and Burdekin Local Governments areas.

field_reports.description:
Southeast Queensland has been severely impacted by two thunderstorms  – one on Christmas Day and one on New Years Day. The most affected Local Government areas are Gold Coast, Logan, and Scenic Rim. 6,000 homes are still without power after the Christmas Day storm. The Bureau of Meteorology issued an urgent warning for dangerous and life-threatening flash flooding on New Years Day. Isolated rainfall totals in some areas for the 24 hour period exceeded 300mm. The storm is expected to continue into Tuesday 02/01. 

 Sadly, there have been seven deaths in the region related to the Christmas Day storms. 

Two Evacuation Centres were stood up on New Years Day on the Gold Coast and some scheduled recovery activities related to the Christmas Day storms were postponed due to the storm.

field_reports.summary: AUS: Cyclone - 12-2023 - Tropical Cyclone Jasper - NT
field_reports.description: The NT Emergency Services team have received an Early Watching briefing for Cyclone Jasper. TC Jasper is now tracking across FNQ and is forecasted to enter the Gulf of Carpentaria on Friday 15 December 2023 as a tropical low. It is anticipated that EX TC Jasper will then continue moving across the gulf towards the NT. There is a possibility that it may re-intensify to cyclone strength as it approaches the NT however this is not confirmed. The BOM will continue to track and report on the movements of Ex TC Jasper in the coming days.  Depending on the cyclone movement and intensity there might be requirement to establish an evacuation centre or sheltering in Darwin.

results.summary: The NT Emergency Services team have received an Early Watching briefing for Cyclone Jasper. TC Jasper is now tracking across FNQ and is forecasted to enter the Gulf of Carpentaria on Friday 15 December 2023 as a tropical low. It is anticipated that EX TC Jasper will then continue moving across the gulf towards the NT. There is a possibility that it may re-intensify to cyclone strength as it approaches the NT however this is not confirmed. The BOM will continue to track and report on the movements of Ex TC Jasper in the coming days. Depending on the cyclone movement and intensity there might be requirement to establish an evacuation centre or sheltering in Darwin. Ex TC Jasper is slowly tracking across Far North Queensland  and is forecasted to enter the Gulf of Carpentaria by Thursday 20 December 2023. There is a low chance of the system redeveloping into a tropical cyclone when it reacheds the Gulf of Carpentaria and forecast predictions now show the system moving back east and away form the Northern Territory.
results.name: AUS: Cyclone - 12-2023 - Tropical Cyclone Jasper - NT

field_reports.description:
On Wednesday 13 December 2023 Tropical Cyclone Jasper crossed the coast of Queensland north of Port Douglas as a Category 2 cyclone. Cyclone shelters and storm tide shelters were established across the communities of Cairns, Port Douglas, Tablelands, Yarrabah, and Cooktown to provide last resort shelter for those at greatest risk. All shelters closed on 14 December once the immediate threat had passed. Additional Evacuation Centres established in the wake of TC Jasper in Redlynch, Smithfield, and Edmonton have also now closed. As at 2 January 2024, the Evacuation Centre in Cooktown continues to operate providing services and accommodation to 13 residents. 

 Multiple communities in North Queensland continue to feel the impacts of flooding associated with Ex-Tropical Cyclone Jasper. This event has significantly impacted eight local government authorities, affecting 26-28 identified areas which have been identified for in person support.

Personal hardship financial assistance is now available for Queensland communities in eligible areas impacted by Tropical Cyclone Jasper. Communities and individuals are actively engaged in the cleanup efforts, and not all locations have had their water, power, and access fully restored. All local government areas (LGAs) have transitioned into the early stages of the recovery process. 

 Affected Local Government Areas (LGA’s) are: Cairns, Cassowary Coast, Cook, Douglas, Hope Vale, Mareeba, Tablelands, Wujal Wujal and Yarrabah.

results.summary:
On Wednesday 13 December 2023 Tropical Cyclone Jasper crossed the coast of Queensland north of Port Douglas as a Category 2 cyclone. Communities on Far North Queensland had undergone five days of preparation in the lead up to the cyclone taking protective measures to secure homes and livelihoods as well as protect life. Cyclone shelters and storm tide shelters were established across the communities of Cairns, Port Douglas, Tablelands, Yarrabah, and Cooktown to provide last resort shelter for those at greatest risk.  

 

Emergency Services agencies (Police, Fire & Rescue, Ambulance, SES) pre-positioned additional teams and resources in close proximity to the expected impact zones for rapid deployment once the Cyclone had passed.  

 

Ex TC Jasper is now moving west bringing continued flood risk to the Cairns and Douglas shire region. There are major flood warnings in place for the Daintree and Mossman rivers, with flash flooding occurring overnight in Mossman resulting in the rapid evacuation of up to 50 people. 

 

From14 December 2023 to current time, the Ex TC Jasper low pressure system has caused heavy and widespread rainfall of more than 600mls to fall in Far North Queensland (FNQ). With the rain not predicted to ease until Tuesday 19 December a dangerous and major flood emergency is occurring across large areas of FNQ. Flash flooding has resulted in emergency evacuations being undertaken with people being rescued from rising flood waters by helicopters and boats. Properties and businesses have been inundated and many communities are now isolated by flood water. Cairns airport has closed hampering efforts to move emergency services agencies to and from the affected areas.

Ex-tropical cyclone Jasper is now a tropical low and continues to slowly track west over Cape York towards the Gulf of Carpentaria. At this stage, there is a low chance of the system redeveloping into a tropical cyclone when it reaches the Gulf of Carpentaria later this week. Some forecast predictions see the system moving back east towards East Arnhem land and back across Cape York Peninsula or into the Coral Sea. 

 

As at Monday 18 December 2023, Ex TC Jasper is causing major flooding including flask flooding across Far North Queensland, with many communities isolated, properties and infrastructure damaged, the closure of Cairns Airport and multiple evacuation centres and places of refuge established.

Planned recovery activity has been delayed due to the current dynamic flood emergency.
results.name: AUS: Cyclone - 12-2023 - Tropical Cyclone Jasper - QLD

field_reports.summary: AUS: Fire - 2023-10 - Queensland -Tara and Kogan Bushfire
field_reports.description:
On Monday 23 October 2023, a large, fast-moving bushfire began burning near Tara in the Western Downs region on Queensland and has since spread to other areas within the region. As at 26th October warnings remain in place with messaging that the area is not safe to return to. There has been more than 11,000 ha burnt, sixteen structures have been destroyed, but further damage not yet assessed. There are multiple road closures throughout the area.

An Evacuation Centre opened at Tara on 24 October 2023, housing 304 displaced people, with an evacuation centre also opened at Chinchilla housing 17 displaced people.

On 25 October 2023, all people from Tara Evacuation Centre relocated to Dalby Evacuation Centre due to threat of fire at Tara. There are reports of 350 people have been evacuated from the region.

Two people have been reported deceased near Tara. There are currently no reports of injury.

GIVIT have launched a Queensland Bushfire 2023 appeal.

field_reports.description:
According to NSW Rural Fire service reports a fire began in Moparrabah, about 30 kilometres west of Kempsey, on the afternoon of Monday 16 October 2023 and has since burnt through more than 10,000 hectares.

Throughout the day more than 1,000 firefighters were active across the state with three fires reaching emergency level. As of 17 October, 70 fires are burning around the state with 30 yet to be contained.

The NSW Rural Fire Service said properties have been lost, but it was not clear how many or if that included any homes.

Two evacuation centres opened at Kempsey (Newcastle Region) and Kyogle (Northern Rivers Region). An evacuation centre set up at the Kempsey Showground West Kempsey with some residents and domestic animals staying on site.

Sadly a man died after the bushfire impacted his property 30km west of Kempsey.

results.name: AUS: Fire - 2023-10 - Kempsey/ Kyogle Bushfires

contacts.name: Debra Shaddock
contacts.title: National Senior Project Officer Emergency Services Response

field_reports.description:
A monsoon and embedded low are generating rains, storms and severe weather in the Daly and Gregory districts within the Northern Territory. A severe weather warning is in place for Barkly, and parts of Carpentaria, Gregory, Barkly and Tanami districts.  A flood watch has been issued for parts of the Top End and Central Inland and Carpentaria Coastal catchments where widespread flooding is expected for the next few days.

Northern Territories Chief Minister signed an emergency declaration covering the communities of Pigeon Hole, Yarralin, Daguragu and Kalkarindji in the northwest. The Upper Victoria River at Kalkarindji peaked last night at 17 metres and is currently at 16.6metres.  The bridge at Kalkarindji submerges when the river level increases above 9.3metres making evacuation difficult.  Houses at Dagaragu have been cut off by floodwaters for the past few days. The communities of Dagaragu, Pigeon Hole, Palumpa and Kalkarindji are currently being evacuated by air to Darwin. The Kalkarindji school is closed.

 

There is the potential for further evacuations in the Daly, Gregory, Barkly, Tanami, Top End and Carpentaria regions, as the number of communities impacted by widespread flooding across part of Northern Territory is expected to rise, with river levels in these districts still yet to peak in some parts.

results.name: AUS: Flood - 2023-03 - Northern Territory

contacts.name: Debra Shaddock
contacts.title: National Senior Project Officer Emergency Services Response

field_reports.summary: AUS: Flood - 2022-07 - Flood New South Wales (NSW)
field_reports.description:
An east coast low developed over the weekend in the central NSW coastal region, bringing heavy rain and strong winds. The areas of Sydney,  Central Coast,  Hunter region,  South Coast, and the Illawarra have experienced torrential rain, damaging winds, flash flooding, coastal erosion, and riverine flooding. One person has reported to have died in floodwaters at Parramatta River.
Although rain rates have mostly eased overnight, heavy rainfall which may lead to flash flooding is still possible today in the Illawarra, Blue Mountains, Sydney Metropolitan and parts of Hunter (including Central Coast) districts today.  A dangerous surf warning remains in place for the exposed coast of the Hunter, Sydney Metropolitan and Illawarra districts.  There are multiple flood warnings in place.

results.name: AUS: Flood - 2022-07 - Flood New South Wales

field_reports.description:
The intense rainfall and thunderstorms that started over southeast Queensland is now affecting part of northern New South Wales. There are currently 4 major and 17 moderate-minor flood warnings in place with two severe weather warnings still current. Heavy rainfall and damaging winds that may lead to flash flooding are forecast for today. Heavy rainfall is expected to last for a few days. 
  
An evacuation warning has been issued for the entire Northern Rivers region of NSW and for low lying parts of Ballina and surrounding areas, with fears that up to 7,000 homes could be affected. The town of Ballina is under evacuation as the Richmond River has burst its banks. Communications are down with communities cut off from essential supplies. Over 1,000 people are in an evacuation centre in Lennox Head. 
Evacuation orders are in place for several Sydney suburbs with concerns about potential failure of Red bank Dam.

Flood levels are falling in Lismore with rain having eased in the catchment area. Water NSW have indicated that Sydney's main reservoir, Warragamba Dam, would likely spill into the Hawkesbury – Nepean flood plain later this week. 
There are 33 evacuation centres currently open across the state. 
 
The Australian Defence Force (ADF) is supporting the NSW government efforts with aerial search and rescue support, civilian evacuation operations and preparing forces to assist in recovery operations.  
 
Five fatalities have been reported to date in NSW. 
NSW SES have received over 6,0000 calls to help affected people has made over 1,000 flood rescues. 17 evacuation orders are in place affecting over 40,000 people while 21 areas are under evacuation warnings affecting 300,000 people. Over 18,000 customers are without power on the NSW north coast with 255 schools closed because of the flooding emergency.  

Disaster Recovery Funding Assistance (DRFA) for flood affected NSW local government areas has been activated.

The week of 21 February, a strong upper low and slow-moving surface trough near the southeast coast of Queensland has produced heavy to intense rainfall and thunderstorms over southeast Queensland. More than 245mm of rain fell in areas around Brisbane, the Lockyer Valley, and Sunshine Coast. The rainfall and major flooding caused dangerous conditions from Hervey Bay to the Gold Coast and west to Toowoomba.

There are no longer any communities that are isolated because of this flood event, in Southeast Queensland.  Further severe thunderstorms have continued to occur, but conditions have now eased, and floods are subsiding. 
On Monday 28 March 2022 an East Coast low affected Southeast Queensland bringing strong winds and heavy rain into areas already very wet from earlier flooding.  
Queensland Police have confirmed the death of two people due to this weather event. A total of 15 fatalities have been confirmed to date. SES (State Emergency Services) is no longer reporting requests for assistance.
As of 21 March, 18,021 damage assessments had been conducted with at least 7 properties destroyed, 1,939 properties assessed as severely damaged, with a further 6,295 as minor to moderately damaged. 

As of 11th April 2022, there are two major and one moderate flood warning in place in Queensland.  Flood releases from all SE QLD gated dams have ceased, with SEQ flood operations centre no longer active. Moderate outflows continue from a number of dams as a result of heavy recent rains in the catchment area. The Bureau of Meteorology has advised that mild to warm weather will continue over this week, with showers expected late in the afternoons.

Housing remains a critical issue with reports of difficulties in accessing grants portals and working with insurance providers. Some affected properties are uninsured with reports of limitations in existing policies impacting claims. Anecdotal reports from recovery hubs indicates forced homelessness as a result of increased rates of domestic violence. 
 
Non-residents and international students have reported difficulties getting assistance with key resources not being available for people from non-English speaking backgrounds.  Concerns are held for refugee populations due to the impact of previous trauma experiences. Agencies present at recovery hubs are facing challenges in providing culturally and linguistically appropriate support.

On 10 March, the Insurance Council of Australia (ICA) reported that 73,823 claims had been received related to the South-East QLD floods. Based on previous flood events the estimated cost of the claims was $1.107 billion.

A strong upper low and slow-moving surface trough has produced heavy to intense rainfall and thunderstorms over southeast Queensland (QLD).  Heavy rain and flooding have continued across the southeast of the state since Tuesday 22 February and are likely to persist. Intense local rainfall has been experienced in many areas. A number of river catchments are now saturated, leading to an increased risk of dangerous and life-threatening flash flooding with a possibility of landslides. Numerous flood and severe storm warnings have been issued across the region with eleven major, six moderate and various minor flood warnings currently in place, most notably from Gympie up to Maryborough.  A further three thunderstorm warnings are also in place. 
 
Rainfall and flash flooding have resulted in road closures across the region. More than 245mm of rain has fallen in areas around Brisbane, the Lockyer Valley and Sunshine Coast. Between 0900hrs Saturday 26 February and 0800hrs Sunday 27 February, 320mm of rain was received at Beerburrum, on the Sunshine Coast. South East Queensland water have commenced flood releases from Wivenhoe, Somerset and North Pine Dams. Roads have been closed downstream from Wivenhoe dam until further notice due to dam releases, combined with river and creek flows downstream of the dam. Ungated dams in the area are also experiencing spillage from excess water. 

Six fatalities have been reported in the last week including one SES volunteer. As at 0930 hrs on Sunday 27/02/2022, approximately 20,000 premises are without power with the worst affected areas being Gympie, Sunshine Coast, Ipswich, Lockyer Valley and Brisbane.   
  
Many road closures are in place including the Bruce Highway which is cut in multiple places between Brisbane and Gympie resulting in major delays for travellers who have been left stranded.

QLD Emergency Services have made 132 rescues overnight as of Sunday 27/02 and have responded to more than 1,800 requests for assistance.

On Saturday 26 February, 700 residents in low-lying areas of Gympie were ordered to evacuate due to flooding from the Mary River. The Bruce Highway is closed on both sides of Gympie. Flood levels are reported to have surpassed the previous 1999 record.  Evacuation centres have been opened at the Gympie Civic Centre and the Gympie Showgrounds.  At 0400 hours on Sunday 27 February an emergency warning was issued by Ipswich City Council for residents in low lying area to evacuate as life threatening flooding was possible due to water releases from Wivenhoe dam. Evacuation centres  opened in Ipswich, Sunshine Coast, Fraser Coast and Moreton Bay Regional Councils.

The intense rainfall and thunderstorms that started over southeast Queensland have impacted large parts of coastal New South Wales, from the Queensland border down to the Victorian border and inland in the Hunter. On 11 March 2022, a National Emergency declaration was made for “significant areas” of New South Wales – Richmond Valley, Lismore, and Clarence Valley local government areas. 

As of Monday 11 April 2022, there are three moderate flood warnings in place across the state. A Southerly change is expected to bring showers, with mild temperatures continuing for the week.

There are five evacuation orders in place and seven evacuation warnings current for NSW.  The Warragamba Dam, located in the Hawkesbury Nepean catchment is currently at 100% of capacity.

There is one evacuation centre currently operational in Richmond. Telecommunications providers have advised that emergency assets have been deployed to evacuation centres in Lismore to support individuals to make and receive calls. Roads remain impacted as a result of flooding, with 25 closures within Lismore City Council area.

The SES have established a flood rescue cell at Metford and airbases at Ballina, Coffs Harbour and Cessnock with ADF among the support agencies. As at 0630 hours on Monday 11 April NSW SES had received 2,657 requests for assistance as a result of this event that commenced on 4th April 2022 with 64 flood rescues undertaken.

There has been two flood related deaths as a result of the current weather event. There is now a total of ten confirmed flood-related fatalities in New South Wales as a result of the 2022 eastern Australia floods.

Housing availability is a significant issue in the northern rivers' region with a large high percentage of properties uninsured in Lismore and surrounds.  A lack of services, due to the scale of disaster and consequential isolation, has left community members feeling abandoned with a shortage of supplies, eftpos facilities, fuel and cash. Lismore City Council has advised that the Dawson Street sewage pump is currently inundated, which could result in sewage overflows. 
 
There are concerns regarding the ongoing psychosocial impacts of the second round of floods in one month on the region. Community members are fatigued, and at their threshold and many feel this is not something they can cope with. Those who were beginning to move belongings back into their homes, or work on rebuilding are potentially going to go through a second round of damages to property.

The intense rainfall and thunderstorms that started over southeast Queensland is now affecting part of northern New South Wales. There are currently 4 major and 15 moderate-minor flood warnings in place with two severe weather warnings current. Heavy rainfall and damaging winds that may lead to flash flooding are forecast for today. Heavy rainfall is expected to last for a few days.

An evacuation warning has been issued for the entire Northern Rivers region of NSW and for low lying parts of Ballina and surrounding areas, with fears that up to 7,000 homes could be affected. The town of Ballina is under evacuation as the Richmond River has burst its banks. Communications are down with communities cut off from essential supplies. Over 1,000 people are in an evacuation centre in Lennox Head. Flood levels are falling in Lismore with rain having eased in the catchment area. Water NSW have indicated that Sydney's main reservoir, Warragamba Dam, would likely spill into the Hawkesbury – Nepean flood plain later this week.
There are 17 evacuation centres currently open across the state.

The Australian Defence Force (ADF) is supporting the NSW government efforts with aerial search and rescue support, civilian evacuation operations and preparing forces to assist in recovery operations. 

NSW SES have received over 6,0000 calls to help affected people has made over 1,000 flood rescues. 17 evacuation orders are in place affecting over 40,000 people while 21 areas are under evacuation warnings affecting 300,000 people. Over 20,000 customers are without power on the NSW north coast with 170 schools closed because of the flooding emergency.

Disaster Recovery Funding Assistance (DRFA) for flood affected NSW local government areas has been activated.

On Friday 4 February an emergency warning was issued for a bushfire burning in the vicinity of Shadforth in the Shire of Denmark, WA. The fire ignited about 9.30am on Friday near the Bayview Rise and McLeod Road intersection in Shadforth.
The bushfire in WA’s south has burnt more than 2300 hectares and forced families to evacuate their homes. Over 150 fire fighters are on the ground with roads closed in the area. Evacuation centres were set up in Denmark, Walpole and at the Albany Leisure and Aquatic Centre, Albany. The Denmark evacuation centre was closed on Friday evening. 

On Saturday 5 February an emergency warning was issued for a bushfire burning in the vicinity of Hester Brook and Bridgetown in the Shire of Bridgetown-Greenbushes, WA, with the  bushfire being out of control and unpredictable.  Authorities issued an urgent plea to the Bridgetown community on Saturday, asking all residents to evacuate as an emergency warning was also issued for Hester Brook late in the evening. Bridgetown hospital and a nursing home were evacuated. An Evacuation centre has been set up at the Basketball Stadium on Rutherford Street in Manjimup, about three hours south of Perth. 150 firefighters battled the blaze and continue to be supported by SES, police and paramedics.

On Sunday 6 February emergency warnings were issued for two fires in WA’s wheatbelt, approximately 250km east of Perth covering the Shire of Narrogin and Wickepin . Farm land has been burnt with reports of at least one home lost. More than 100 fire fighters battled the bushfire as resources were stretched across the region. An evacuation centre has been set-up at the Pingelly Recreation Centre.

At least four homes have been confirmed as destroyed in Denmark with one home destroyed in Bridgetown. The fire impacted transmission lines supplying Bridgetown, Manjimup and Beenyup substations causing outages in the greater surrounding area, including areas West to Augusta. Approximately 1800 households are experiencing power outages which have also led to disruptions to telecommunications. A number of schools in the bushfire affected areas are closed today.

Ex-Tropical Cyclone Seth caused exceptionally heavy rains in the Wide Bay and Burnett region in Queensland from Thursday 06/01, with some areas reporting between 300- 600mm overnight on Friday 07/01. Further rain continued over the course of the weekend, but with much lower intensity. There was major flooding across the region, leading to power outages and numerous road closures. Sections of the Bruce highway were impacted and some of the road washed away. Railways were also drastically affected, with no freight or passenger trains running north of Gympie, putting further pressure on an already strained supply chain. The Fraser Coast Mary River catchment area, particularly the towns of Maryborough and Tiaro, have been severely impacted. As of 12/01/2022 flood levels are falling, and roads re-opening - power outages remain in four suburbs only. •	Major roads to the west of Fraser Coast LGA remain impacted by closures. 
As Local government  moves to the recovery phase, the focus will be assisting community members to access grants, and with the clean-up. Debris in, and contamination of the water may result in sickness or breeding of mosquitoes. The public have been advised not to enter the water, including any beaches, due to these risks.
Rural communities have been identified as in need of psychological support in the aftermath of the flooding, as many have lost livestock and will be confronted with dead, missing or injured animals on their properties. 
Australian Government and Queensland Government Grants have been made available for access by eligible flood affected communities.

On Thursday 2 December, as a result of heavy rainfall and significant river level rises observed along the Macintyre River upstream of the townships of Boggabilla and Toomelah, residents from those communities were advised that as flood waters approach they will become isolated with road access cut. As the river nears its predicted peak it is expected that the townships will be inundated by floodwaters. Residents from the community of Boggabilla, which sits on the NSW-QLD border, have been evacuated to Moree East Public School. 73 individuals have been accommodated for including 34 children, with the centre is operating 24x7. An Evacuation order has been issued for both towns for 11 am Friday 3 December for 450 – 550 residents (worst case scenario).  A housing contact centre has been opened up to consider vacancy options. As at 8.30am AEDT on Friday 3 December evacuation orders for both townships are in place.

Red Cross Response
On Thursday 2 December Red Cross was activated to provide meet and greet and psychosocial support services an evacuation centre in the town of Moree in Northern NSW. One Red Cross volunteer is assisting in the evacuation centre. Recovery and outreach planning has commenced with representation at local and district level disaster management meetings.

On Wednesday, 1st December 2021, heavy rainfall commenced in Queensland’s Southern Border town of Inglewood, resulting in rising floodwater and causing the evacuation of hundreds of residents overnight. Flood waters are now receding in Inglewood, with the water now moving downstream towards the township of Yelarbon.  
Flood modelling indicated that a significant portion of Yelarbon town could potentially be inundated by flood water on Wednesday evening, compromising essential infrastructure (sewerage system). An emergency alert was issued for nearby Leyburn, and residents in Yelarbon were told to evacuate to Goondiwindi, approximately 50km away where an evacuation centre had been established at the Showgrounds.  Authorities arranged for residents to be bussed to Goondiwindi due to the damage to roads. 
The Bureau of Meteorology has predicted a major flood peak near 10.7 metres likely at Goondiwindi late Friday 3 December - similar to the 2011 flood peak. The town levee is expected to hold at this height however the trigger for evacuation of Goondiwindi is 10.8 meters.  Planning is underway by authorities should the levee breach.
A number of homes and properties have been inundated with floodwater, with residents reporting loss of property including cars with more than 400 roads throughout the state flooded.
Authorities are warning further rainfall will force water from dams and catchments that are already overflowing into rivers and creeks across the state.

Red Cross Response
Four Red Cross volunteers supported 16 residents from Yelarbon staying in the Evacuation Centre in Goondiwindi to return home during a temporary easing of floodwaters, which allowed safe passage on the morning of Friday 3 December. There are no remaining residents in the Evacuation Centre. Red Cross volunteers remain on standby in Goondiwindi in the event more evacuations are required. QLD have also received a request to provide early recovery support for residents of Inglewood with details are to be confirmed. Teams remain on standby to provide recovery services and outreach support across a number of flood-impacted communities in the coming days with planning underway for potential scale up of operations. Red Cross continues representation at local and district level disaster management group meetings.

contacts.name: Debra Shaddock
contacts.title: National Coordinator Preparedness and Response Emergency Services

field_reports.description:
At 09:15 hours on 22 September a magnitude 5.9 earthquake struck at a depth of 10km near Mansfield, in north-east Victoria. Tremors were felt across Victoria, New South Wales, Canberra and as far away as Adelaide (SA) and Launceston (TAS).  The earthquake is one of the largest ever recorded in eastern Australia, with tremors lasting around 20 seconds in Melbourne and up to a minute closer to the epicentre.

Several aftershocks measuring 4.1, 3.5 and 3.1 in magnitude have been recorded, with experts warning smaller aftershocks may continue to occur for months. Further information regarding the earthquake can be found on the Geoscience Australia website: http://www.ga.gov.au/. 

Currently there are no reported serious injuries or fatalities, however several buildings across Victoria have sustained minor damage and impact assessments will continue over the coming days. Minor disruptions to public transport have been reported and 35,000 households across Melbourne were temporarily left without power, with most outages now resolved.

At this stage Australian Red Cross has not been formally activated to respond to this event. The Victorian Emergency Services team is proactively linking with State Government authorities and local representatives to prepare in the event that support is required.

Australian Red Cross Emergency Services will continue to monitor events and inform of any developments.

contacts.name: Debra Shaddock
contacts.title: National Coordinator Preparedness and Response Emergency Services

field_reports.description:
On the 11th April, the Western Australia (WA) Department of Fire and Emergency Services (DFES) issued a cyclone red alert for an area South of Carnarvon to Lancelin, a distance of 780 kms, warning people in that area that they were in danger and needed to take immediate shelter from a category three cyclone. Tropical Cyclone Seroja (TC Seroja) made landfall as a category three cyclone at 8pm on 11th April. Wind gusts of up to 170km per hour were recorded around Kalbarri, with storm surges and heavy rain resulting in flooding in a number of locations.
On the 18th April, an “All clear with caution” was announced for the area between Carnarvon and Lancelin, extending inland to Paynes Find in the Goldfields-Midlands and Midwest Gascoyne
32,000 homes and businesses lost power. Around 1,693 homes and businesses remain without power in various locations. 16 local government areas have reported damage and destroyed homes. No major issues identified with water supply. Landline phones and mobile networks in parts of the affected area remain inoperable. 
Emergency services personnel are assessing damage to more than 1,074 buildings caused by Tropical Cyclone Seroja. Rapid Damage Assessment Teams have completed over 1,750 assessments so far, 300 more than initial expectations. DFES has 500 personnel in the Midwest Gascoyne Region assisting with recovery efforts. Storm damage teams have arrived from New South Wales, South Australia and Victoria to help, along with Australian Defence Force personnel.
